subject: Sleep
title: REM Sleep and Depression
description: Learn REM Sleep and Depression in one minute.

hook.text: Depressed people enter REM sleep faster and stay in it longer than healthy people. Their brains crave it.

buildup.text: Healthy sleepers reach REM after about 90 minutes. Depressed patients often reach it in 45 to 60 minutes.

discovery.text: Excessive REM may intensify emotional processing, reinforcing negative memories and depressive rumination.

twist.text: Most antidepressants powerfully suppress REM sleep. This may be part of how they actually work.

climax.text: The REM-depression link suggests that too much emotional processing during sleep can maintain the illness.

punchline.text: In depression, the brain may dream its way deeper into sadness.

quiz.question: How does REM sleep differ in depressed patients?
options: They have no REM sleep at all
They enter REM faster and spend more time in it
Their REM cycles are identical to healthy sleepers
